info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 24 at 5:41PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
info.description:
Tropical Storm Bauloi (26W) continues to move west into the Philippine Sea and strengthen, away from Palau and Yap, and is currently located near 9.7N 132.6E. Much of the convection is focused to the west and southwest of the circulation center, but locally heavy showers will remain a concern for Palau over the next few days, as a moist, convergent monsoon pattern sets up behind TS Bauloi. Palau has received 2.5 to 3 inches of rainfall so far, and another 1 to 2 inches are possible over the next several days. Landslide potential is diminishing but the possibility remains, especially where soils have become saturated from prior heavy rainfall.
A Small Craft Advisory remains in effect for Palau with 8 to 10 ft seas expected through tonight as TS Bualoi pulls away, mainly over western coastal waters. Seas are expected to relax below hazardous small craft levels Thursday morning. Additionally, elevated northerly and westerly swell in the wake of TS Bualoi are expected to maintain hazardous surf of 7 to 9 ft along north and west facing reefs over the next day or so. Yap will mainly feel a west to southwest swell, and hazardous surf is anticipated along west and south facing reefs there.
Residents and mariners should monitor the latest forecasts for the region at weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts and any information shared by WSO Palau and WSO Yap for their local regions, as well as JTWC bulletins under WTPN31 PGTW.

parameter.value: TROPICAL STORM BUALOI (26W) MOVING FROM PALAU AND YAP, HEAVY RAIN AND GUSTS CONTINUE... ...ELEVATED SWELL TO MAINTAIN HAZARDOUS SURF THE NEXT FEW DAYS

area.areaDesc: Yap; Melekeok; Airai; Koror; Peleliu; Angaur
